Toothbrush for people with disabilities: Create a toothbrush that is designed for people with disabilities, such as those with limited mobility or dexterity. The toothbrush could have a larger handle, a flexible brush head, and adjustable bristles to make it easier to use.

Toothbrush with a built-in timer: A toothbrush with a built-in timer can help users brush their teeth for the recommended two minutes. The timer can be set for a specific amount of time, and the toothbrush can automatically stop after that time has elapsed.

Toothbrush with a built-in UV light: A toothbrush with a built-in UV light can help users detect and remove stains from their teeth. The light can be used to inspect the teeth after brushing and can help identify areas that need additional attention.
Toothbrush with a built-in tongue scraper: A toothbrush with a built-in tongue scraper can help remove bacteria and debris from the tongue, which can improve oral health and breath.

Toothbrush with a built-in pressure sensor: A toothbrush with a built-in pressure sensor can help users brush their teeth with the right amount of pressure. The sensor can detect when the user is applying too much pressure and can provide feedback to help them adjust their technique.
